He gives a lot of hints in the review classes. He grades exams very generously. You have to put in effort, but the class is genuinely interesting.

This was definitely a challenging course, but I think that it was well taught and organized. If you put in some effort (attending lecture and doing the homework), I think you'll do well in his class. The lecture was very helpful. Grading was a fairly strict on homework and projects, but the exams seemed to be graded forgivingly.
It's honestly absurd how we have two homework assignments due the same week. And it's even more absurd we have a project due right before the final exam the week after.

1. Is strict for unnecessary reasons. 
2. Very rigid
3. Looks for tiniest of reasons to take away points

Took this guy Autumn of 2020. I did really well in the class, but I know others who struggled and got screwed over. He gives too much work, does not give care and aid towards misunderstandings, and just expects us to know via textbook only. Dumped a lengthy research report 2 weeks before finals. Learned a lot, but expects you to no life the course.

Did not know much about programming but taught. Made the peer review simply became an Oral English test. Did not allow students to play their video demo on YouTube pretending to be fair. Last reports required more than 8 pages and 10 font size, totally a waste of time

This course became a nightmare for me. He always said wants to be fair but the thing is not. He made most of homework to be group tasks and gave same points to each one. It then became if other members did not work, you had to make it up all by yourself. The last report is 5000 words by yourself. Silly peer review simply removed your most points.

I think he was tough, but definitely a good professor. Some of the courses are easier at OSU so I don't think a lot of the students were prepared for this level of work, but it's engineering, you have to adapt. I came out of this class knowing far more about comp arch than I ever imagined and feel proud of the work I accomplished.

Acts condescending when you ask a question and never helps students directly. Always says "oh you shoulda read the textbook" even if you did read it and makes you regret asking a question. Hostile, tough grader, gives tons of assignments---> avoid
All my time was contributed to this class but still cannot get a good grade.

I recommend that you stay away from this professor. The work load for this course is more than any other 5000 level course offered. It's like the professor thinks that all of your time should be devoted to 5362 and nothing else. The course is is even worse online now that we're not in school due to COVID19.

He has been making this class harder and harder every year. He gives massive projects and very little help in office hours. The projects used to be group assignments but now they're solo. Expect to write many hundreds of lines for each one. I would take this course with someone else if possible.

no partial credit at all. Number of questions is small which means each question takes up lots of credits. Any little careless will not be forgiven and you will lose all the points. So common to see 70+,60+ in the class. Foolish grader overall!

A great professor to work with. Understanding, generous, laid back in terms of grading and lecturing style. And yeah, he is hilarious on a regular basis as well! This class is you get what you give, put in the effort, you will learn and get good grades. Attendance is optional.

Attend lecture and read the book to know how to do any of the problems. Homeworks are tougher example problems and tests are tougher homework problems. His tests are open note. You need to put in a lot of effort to do well. Curves very little at the end of the course, if at all. Offers help when asked, but may not be necessarily helpful.
Tests have more difficult questions than discussed in class.
It's not hard to get an A from this class as long as you finish all the homework.
Just simply don't take his class he grades his exam very strictly no partial credit at all. Wrong final answer 0 point and the final letter grade is very hard also just try to avoid him.
exams are open notes and open book, it is easy and the professor gives extra bonus. It is not hard to get an A in this class.
The final is exam is hard and it's all about memorizing. It should be open book or open notes. And his office hour is short and hard to come.

I had a terrible time in this course. She seemed upset with students the entire time and she was not friendly outside of class. (There were some rude students but it is not fair to the rest of us.) Also the in class examples were good for learning but way too simple to help us do the HW so where else would we get that knowledge

It felt like she didn't want to be there and didn't like the students. It was a 'flipped' classroom with online recorded lectures, I watched youtube lectures and went to the review sessions instead and it was fine.
She's alright. She taught the material in a somewhat effective way. She just didn't like teaching and always came late to class. She has a very annoying voice and personality.

Overall, she was a good professor but a few things she did really annoyed me. Her flipped classroom model makes a 3 hr credit course seem like a 6 hr credit course. She has 3 chances to teach this content in person, but instead she does a WAY over simplified example, then has students complete a much harder participation problem. Not bad otherwise.

Her flipped classroom model was actually good. She explains all the logic you need to know in order to tackle the problems. Set aside time to watch all the videos. I typically did this on weekends. Going to the review days are actually helpful and prepare you for the homework. Tests are easier than the homeworks. Only gets hard after module 8.

This class is not an easy A, and you'll need to put in a lot of effort into homeworks and exam prep to pull it off. However, some of the reviews on here aren't fair. The class (particularly the second half) has some tough content, but Dr. Fernandez's lecture videos are very efficient and example-based. Go to office hours when you're stuck.

The homework grading is exceptionally harsh and rarely has direct correlation to exam content. The flipped classroom model she uses is...passable, however we once again see a huge disparity between the difficulty of example problems and homework/exams. She relies exclusively on videos to teach content which can make it very difficult to learn

Her lectures and lecture notes are top tier. Unfortunately, this class had one singular section so there was a ton of people in it which led to a flipped classroom model, so it is hard to fully blame her for this. The homeworks are hard but pretty short. The exams are very hard, as every point is consequential to the grade.
could learn a thing or five from nick painter if she wants to continue doing flipped classroom

I don't know if I'm stupid, am not an ECE major, or if it was the professor, but I put quite a bit of effort into this class and took away literally nothing from it. Exams and homeworks were extremely difficult and with low averages. Hate the "flipped classroom" model. At least the final was take home. Lab was cool.

The flipped classroom model sucks and doesn't care if watching 7 15 min lectures is convenient or not. She thinks her exams are like the practice problems, but you could find maybe one problem in the homeworks/lectures that are like the exam problems. She claimed in class she teaches us using so many examples but she does not. good luck with her.

Makes 3 credit like 6 credit.
And the grading on midterm are so tough

This class is made harder than Physics 1250 due to her flipped classroom. She grades hw so hard. No late assignments whatsoever. Midterms are very hard and conducted on those tiny desks at Hitchcock auditorium. Just take the class at Columbus state instead.
Avoid if possible. This professor will make a 3 credit class feel like a 6 credit class. As a CSE major, the content is pointless and nothing you learn will ever be used post grad.

I thought she did a good job with her lectures and gave lots of extra practice problems for each module that could be used to study. The class had tough homework problems, but I felt they prepared me for the exam. She set lots of TA office hours to help too. She could be hard to access, so I'd recommend using the TAs and starting HW early.

Professor Fernandez is very receptive and fair. I enjoyed the structure of her class, and her lectures were clear. I did struggle with the first exam but knew what to expect for the following ones. I learned a lot and would take her again.

She's a new professor and she is trying her best, however, she doesn't answer emails sometimes. Her explanations in office hours and her lectures are hard to follow. I would verify everything she says on Carmen because she sometimes posts wrong information and forgets to correct such as the exam time, etc.
Had great slides and uploaded all lectures and annotations for reference. Had short in-class participation assignments and course material didn't go too fast.

Assign long hard homework. No correlation between homework and exams. The exams are painfully hard and the practice exam is little to no help. Overall a very challenging and test heavy class be ready to spend a lot of time reviewing the material easily should be a four to five credit hour class.

Dr. Fernandez is one of my favorite lecturers. Her slides are amazing, and the lectures are very hands on. Just get ready to learn a lot of new concepts. Her midterms are pretty challenging, but she has so much prep material on Carmen that helped me a lot. You can tell she wants you to learn, and I love that. Would take her again in a heart beat.

She is strict, does not accept late work, and the homework is due Friday at 7PM for some reason. Attendance is not mandatory, but she has an in-class pop quiz every other class so you definitely need to go. Her Carmen organization is amazing and she posts the annotated class slides and recordings. She is hard to contact by email (doesn't respond).

She was an amazing lecturer - slides are extremely well-organized and fitted with examples that help you learn exactly what you need to know. HW could be overly challenging, but was great preparation for exams. She is an extremely fair and available professor who genuinely wants to see students succeed and actually learn the material.

She is a great professor! Homework was a little rough but office hours helped a lot. The exams were straightforward but the final was take home and was kinda rough. I'd recommend pushing her to do in-person exams but overall a really great professor!

Professor Puentes is a straightforward teacher and gets the job done well. I thought the exams were fair and she did a good job preparing us for them. My only complaint is I wish she occasionally had in-class participation assignments which meant you had to go to class, and I prefer to watch online. Solid professor. I said 5/5 but I'd say 4.5/5.

Great prof. She conveys material and answers questions clearly and in an easy-to-understand way. In-class participation is graded via a pop quiz once every 2 weeks or so(randomly) but it is only completion.

She is a friendly, good lecturer. HW problems were solvable but you had to start them a day or 2 before. Only annoying things were that HW was due at 7 and that she does not share the answers to exams, you have to go to office hours. I thought the final and midterms were fair, with the midterms being harder than the final.

Professor Fernandez does a great job of structuring her lectures and she always tells you the exact steps you need to take to solve problems. Just don't get lazy on the weeks when the content is easy. If you understand the basics from the first half of this course the second half will be a breeze.

If this class was not required for my major I would not take it. Isabel explains the content well, but the lecture and content are boring. Isabel had plenty of extra problems and those helped greatly. Overall, she was alright and her extra content helped. I just thought the material was uninteresting.

Make sure to go to class because your attendance matters. The class moves pretty fast and it is a tough class in general, but she does a good job of teaching the material, as well as providing students additional resources to do well on exams.

Favorite professor all semester! Modules were very well organized and the lectures are easy to understand! Homework comes straight from lectures although prepare for them to take time if your new to this content! Overall decent teacher and not hard to do well in if you put in some effort!

Class content is mostly easy but picks up fast towards the end of the semester. The online lecture videos are pretty good. If you take good notes you will likely not have much trouble in this class. The homework can be a little difficult but she grades very generously. Overall, a very nice professor whose class isn' too difficult to do well in.

Class periods covered about 1/4 of the needed material. 5-9 lecture videos (2-3 hours combined) were posted each week that are not covered in class. Because 1 student put an exam on Chegg, the entire class had to come in person for a final exam after taking no exams in person the whole semester. That person should've been punished, not everyone.

Isabel has been my favorite professor thus far. This my only class that I am truly learning the material in and am enjoying! She is super kind and genuinely wants to help. The first midterm was a breeze, but the second one was fairly difficult. That being said, I would definitely still recommend her; this is a tough class, but she makes it doable!

Isabel is very clear and breaks down difficult topics and makes them easy to understand. Homework and exams were very difficult so working on homework and studying with friends was essential for success. She is a very fair grader and her lecture slides are incredibly useful. She was very accessible outside of class for extra help as well

Amazing teacher, I had her for 2020 a few semesters ago. I wanted to add my comments because a lot of people are giving the wrong ideas. The ones that are whining about her class are more likely to be CSE majors that are required to take the class. If you like circuits you will like the class and do well. Homeworks are much harder than the exams
The material isnt easy. There is consistent homework but its not intolerable. Shes flexible and considerate. Shes clear on her expectations but also fair. Do the work and youll be fine!

2020 is a very hard class is my view. In the online version, there are a LOT of lectures with an okay number of examples. Homeworks are difficult and there is one per week. There is also a weekly check-in with more examples Tests are not as tricky. Biggest problem with this professor is it is hard to contact, as she does not read email timely.

Easy exams and generally stress-free. But if you expect to actually learn something from the class then prepare to learn it on your own. Lecture examples were miles from what she gave on the homework sets. I am pretty sure she just copied the homework problems from some other institutions' files.

I was in the online section for 2020. It was really well organized section but I felt like the lectures were a little lacking. The most helpful part was the examples provided. I am not sure if I would take this class in person with this instructor but online it was fine. Just expect to be teaching yourself, somewhat.
Great teacher.

Lectures were sometimes boring and repetitive, but gave lots of examples. In-class work is worth a lot. Homeworks were sometimes long and required you to think. Exams were relatively easy and she gives lots of partial credit. Labs were long, dull, and barely related to the lectures, but those are done with a different professor.

Professor Fernandez is hands down the best professors I've had (EE senior here). She completely covers all fundamentals before building on them and does lots of relevant examples. HWs are reasonable and cover learned material. I feel like the low ratings here are just whiny sophomore who are surprised they actually have to learn and put in effort.
Easily the worst class I've ever taken at this university. The subject matter is interesting but I'd recommend taking a light course load with this class otherwise you'll get lost fast.
Don't like her. Lectures are useless and you have to teach yourself all the material. Kind EVIL!

Dr. Fernandez is a new prof and improved greatly after her first semester, and is such a caring person. Exams are easier than homework, and she is a lenient grader (won't take off points for dumb mistakes). The grade letter distribution on exams had most students getting above 90%. As easy of a giant-lecture engineering intro class as you can get.

Not a bad professor overall. Her handwriting is atrocious so good luck trying to comprehend the slides she posts online. Grade is well-balanced between HWs, labs, and exams and she drops some of your lowest HW and lab grades. Exams are true to the HW so make sure you're very comfortable with the HW and practice exam problems and you'll be fine.

Giant lecture hall for a course most CSE majors really don't want to take puts any professor in a rough position. Lectures were not all that great. Dropped lowest scores on a few categories of stuff (hw, quizzes, etc.) and curved a bit.
This professor is decent. The pace of the class is very fair and provides plenty of examples of each concept. She uses PowerPoints and writes notes during class.

I didn't feel like she wanted me to go to her office hours except to pick up homework. I guess it makes sense since she has 300 students. The homeworks are very hard but usually you can find the answers on chegg if you wait closer to the due date. The exams are way easier than the homeworks but I still messed up and didn't understand anything

I had her for her first year teaching but the way she set up class is the way I think all classes should be set up. Homework was difficult as well as example problems but tests were much easier which made the class extremely reasonable.

It was her first year teaching and it showed. She was a good professor in most aspects but had a semi short temper and got annoyed by some of the typical things students do. Overall I would recommend but get ready to study, it is not an easy class.

Isabel is new to teaching. Her first year was a little rough. I think she is well spoken, just a teeny, tiny bit of an accent and she is kind of soft spoken. I do think shes a good professor, however I think she should focus a bit more on examples for specific circuits that will be on the exams. If you dont understand visit her outside class!!!!!

Professor is okay in person but he made us come to lab on election day and he made a sarcastic Canvas post a week in advance. This lab was more important than going to the polls and voting for the next POTUS.

In a class project, a group member included plagiarized content. While the rest of us were unaware of this issue, the entire group was reported to COAM. This caused me a lot of stress and left me feeling traumatized. He never responded to my emails nor attended to the lab himself, which significantly impacted me. never seen him.

His lecture videos are awful and the lab portion of this course is a disgrace. You follow the videos step by step, but gain no real understanding of what's going on. Course is an easy A, just a waste of time and could be taught so much better.

A teacher that has no empathy for students. Cannot put himself in the shoes of his students. Uses his doctorate to reuse lab videos from 2 years ago and then takes a salary like he even deserves it. He uses the TA to speak to the students, probably hasn't helped anyone these past few semesters

Dr. Chappman is completely disorganized and had absolutely no idea how to teach a lab. He gives lab assignments but doesn't even know how his own code works. There is no reason he should be teaching. His quiz averages were 60%. He also has a lab report due after every lab. This is the only B that I have gotten at OSU so far.
Homework is pretty challenging, exams are open notes and pretty easy. If you understand homework well you will do great in this class.
Pretty Okay
Dr. Z can seem strict at first, but she genuinely cares about the success of her students. She is very responsive to messages/emails. She also has great lectures. Just make sure to attend class.

This is the third class I've had with Dr. Z (3090 and 5463) and she is an absolute gem. She may come off as a tough person, but she very much cares about everyone and your success. Many resources are available and she has some of the best TA's to help with your project and working on it. The ECE department should keep her at all costs

Dr. Z is a tough love type of professor that helps build your writing and presenting skills throughout the capstone. She comes off coarse and gives feedback bluntly, but your grade won't suffer even if she grills you. She facilitated some great projects and is breathing some new life into the ECE department at OSU.
Dr. Z is caring and very responsive to students. Assignments can be a bit difficult, but she gives a good amount of time for them and emphasizes what's important in lectures.

One of the ECE department's best. It's an intro course, but it is quite hard especially for ECE students. Programming assignments are lengthy and you need a solid group to get it done. Her lectures combine theory with reality. Exams are more than fair and she provides a lot of help. If you put in the effort, a worthwhile class to take!

Had her for 3090, 5463 (fall), 3551 (spring), and capstones. She is a must for robotics. Workload and exam are pretty fair. No curve but give a bit extra credits. Come to lectures, if you need extra help, office hours are very helpful. As long as you are willing to put in some work, and have a growth mindset, you will be fine. Great lecture slides.

Workload was fair, and homeworks were graded easily, often for completion only. Lectures could be fast, so it is better to have the slides downloaded on your own device and just follow along with her examples. It is not hard to get an A if you complete the homework and make a good cheat sheet for the exams.

It's a 1 credit class so there aren't many assignments. Start early so you can ask for feedback and you'll be fine. She came across as tough the first couple of lectures, but she seemed to get better and better as the weeks went on. Not a difficult class if you pay attention.

Dr Z is one of the best professor I have ever had. You do need to show up to class as she does participation grades where you need to get a passcode she only release in class. But other than that she is the best teacher I have had at OSU. Her exams are extremely fair and she won't take a ton of points off if you mess something up.

Dr. Z was passionate and really cared about our understanding and success. I did think the amount of homework was too much for a 1 credit hour class. I understand that technical writing/communication is important and she wants the class to be 2 credit hours, but it was too much research and writing for 1 credit hour. Not a tough grader, though.

Understanding, helpful, and caring! Class is a reasonable amount of work, but expect to learn the material from more of a birds-eye view (i.e., Dr. Z's way of teaching is more 'get the general gist of what's going on' rather than 'know every small detail about circuits' - which IMO was beneficial. Strongly recommend - fair class to get an A w/ work

Dr. Z is very personable and creates a very relaxed, engaging, and surprisingly NOT boring environment for all students. Very passionate in teaching, and takes time to get to know each and every one of her students by name and various traits. She is also very responsive to feedback and emails. It is definitely worth taking a class with her!

Dr. Z is a wonderful professor in the ECE department. She shows a lot of passion and is a very relaxed individual while lecturing. She likes to roast people in class but it's totally relatable and gets the students engaged!

Dr. Z is probably one of the best newest edition that the ECE department needed. Even though her exams are challenging, she does her best to prepare you for it, not only in class but during office hours. Dr. Mchperson hired her for a reason, to make sure he has a good replacement. She is also probably one of the smartest women in ECE department.

She really only cares about the students learning. As long as you put effort into her class and show that you care you will get an easy A. She grades very easily and grades based off your thought process and how much work you put in.

She was very considerate and caring of all students. Would consistently take extra time to review topics and answer any and all questions during the lectures. Midterms were easy and review sessions were very helpful.

This was her first class taught at OSU, so take this review with a grain of salt. I took it online and the lectures were incredibly boring. This class was definitely one reason I didn't go the CE route. Even though the class sucked it was not too difficult once you learned the material.

She's very strict and harsh in grading. My concept was wrong for the first question, so she only gives 1 point to the rest of related questions though my steps for the wrong concept are right. I lost a lot of points but i dont think she cares of her students. Her hw is also very long. I regret taking class with her. So please avoid.

Very harsh professor. I highly recommend taking in it with someone else if you could. Her homeworks and exams take a long time, and they are graded in a very harsh way. And I really regret taking her course

If anyone from the department is reading, please just get another teacher for this class. I don't understand what I'm paying for. I'm just learning everything by myself. It's like I don't have other classes too

Very bad professor. Her exams are too long. And she really enjoys making things much harder for the students. She wants students to suffer through out the semester. Ohio State should have a better professor to teach this course. I blame the University for having a bad professor like her.
One of the worst professor that I had in my life. She always try to make things more difficult for students. She also doesn't know how to teach. Avoid her.

This might have been her first time teaching 3040, I'm not sure. But the lectures were very difficult to follow. However, she does care about students and gives great career advice on the material which is a breath of fresh air.

Class is not hard but she isn't a good professor. I don't really pay attention in class because it's hard to understand her explanations. Instead I just go back over the material later to learn everything.

Julia is very caring professor. She cares that you understand the material rather than just going through it. She actually slowed down to make sure we understand before moving on. I suggest you don't take any notes and just focus listening on the lecture. She records all the lectures. Office hours are very helpful to go to. And she is cute tho.

Do not take this professor. The lectures are disorganized and hard to understand. The only thing that helps is the textbook. Material on midterms are not hard but they are very very long, thus making exams hard. She is extremely difficult to contact via email and her office hours do not help.
Not only a tough grader and awful speaker to give boring classes. He even charged some students of helping sign in other students' names without any evidence.
Very knowledgeable in his field professor. Although it is almost impossible for him to transfer his entire knowledge, he does well to try to help student understand.
Boring lectures and unnecessary loads of lengthy homework
The class was mandatory to meet master's requirements and I think they just waist our time

Atilla is great and communicates the material as clearly as possible. I found sometimes the topics were explained better by other sources, leaving me confused in lecture. He gave brutally difficult homework and exams, and grades reflected this. However, he understands the class is hard and curves generously in the end.

The course material is very difficult to truly comprehend. No matter who's teaching the course the material will still be hard. But Atilla is an extremely bright and understanding professor. The class has a generous curve and if you stay engaged and truly make an effort to at least somewhat understand the material you will be just fine
Good teacher. you will learn a lot. Take him
He is super nice and helpful.  Class is hard, but it is ECE Signals and Systems.  Really good at giving you the materials you need to succeed.

Atilla is a humble, nice Prof. He is really smart, much smarter than you thought. The class material is a little hard. He made his class easy to understand. You actually can learn things in his class.

This guy really should have a higher rating. One of the more quality professors I've had in EE. Relatively new, so the ratings listed might be when he was starting out. Went at a reasonable pace. Very conscious of students' workloads. Midterms were challenging, homework was never too hard, and the final was easy. Highly recommend for control class.
Know the materials very well. Make great effort to teach the course well. Kind and helpful if you have any questions. Hard exams. But you learn the things after the course.

Relatively difficult assignments and exams. Made his greatest effort to make his lectures clear and have students learn, but didn't seem terribly interested in the subject matter. Final grade was slightly higher than expected.
Very difficult assignments and exams. But the course is interesting. Posts lectures, solutions and grades on Carmen. Liberal with the final grade!
Uses alto of technology in class, which is good. Need to work to get an A.
Once put a problem on a midterm, in his own words, "because I knew you would all fail it". Would post slides but only the blank versions. Worst teacher I ever had about testing and good assignments.

very interesting material and well explained. The only problem is examples in class are easy compared with the homework and tests. So understanding the examples in class doesn't help you on homework. Needs to hold more office hours. His use of technology is great and refreshing though. I'd reccomend him!

This professor cares about the class and tries to be helpful although more office hour and better examples would be nice.  Homework is hard and long but if you try to understand it rather than just completing it, it would help you on the exam.  Exams are fair but really test your understanding of the materials.

Knows what he is teaching. Notes were helpful and the homeworks, midterms and finals were application of the course. Though the no. of problems worked out in the class were less and not helpful. In a nutshell, the class was good and would recommend it to my friends

I agree with those before me who say the hw and exams are hard.. however, I used his office hours every week and he always cleared things up. He's helpful, he just tries to test our knowledge a little too thoroughly. After thinking I would tank in the class, I got an A-. Bottom line: Ask him lots of questions and attend class, you'll be all right.

Teaches only theory with almost no examples(and the ones he does do are somewhat useless). The book is also almost all theory. Midterms/Finals were hard with not big basis on Homework. I would not recommend this to somebody who has a hard time following only theory.

Lectures are clear.  He is helpful in office hours. Exams are finishable in allotted time and really do test your understanding. However, examples in lecture are much simpler than homework or exam questions.  He does not hold enough office hours. Exam questions tend to be shockingly different than what you've seen before in homework or lectures.
The teacher was Kind hearted but his exams were much different from homeworks and reviews. The textbooks examples were also hard to comprehend.

Notes in class are clear and easy to read.  Knows how to use a computer unlike many other prof who were born before the 1900.  No prob worked out in class.  HW is more complicated than notes, midterm more complicated than hw, and final more than midterm.

Notes in class are clear and easy to read.  Knows how to use a computer unlike many other prof who were born before the 1900.  No prob worked out in class.  HW is more complicated than notes, midterm more complicated than hw, and final more than midterm.

Horrible.  He has lots of easy examples in class, and posts his notes!...Or, rather, his blank notes templates.  Unhelpful in office hours, unable to answer any questions, unable to teach.  The last 3 weeks or so out of 10 were spent on ECE 600 material.  Seriously.  We finished the syllabus so he went on...but didn't give us any examples or good h
All examples that are worked in class are easy. Enjoy them because you wont see anything like them in the homework, midterms, or textbook. There cannot be a more difficult person on the planet!

Lectures are good but sometimes not enough to fully explain important things. If you can, go to the HKN tutors they can help with the homework. Lets you have cheat sheets for the tests. Stay caught up in the lectures. Good thing he always posts the recorded ones on carmen if you need to refer back.

Not nearly enough explanation given in lecture to be able to properly do the homework and exams. Extremely surface level explanation of concepts, and brushes over explaining what many concepts even are at a fundamental level. Frequently have to utilize other resources to understand the material. Seems to grade fairly leniently though

Professor Lee is nice. The class is structured nicely, there are mini-exams every few weeks and one homework due every week. However, his teaching style is not compatible with me as a student. He brushes over topics quickly, then assigns us homework questions that require techniques that were not covered in class.
Worse professor ever. Cannot clearly explain a single concept.

He's a great teacher. Lectures are fairly good. Homework is really tough. Tests are even tougher. Exams are open book, notes, cheatsheets. Gives a HUGE curve at the end. He is very understanding and easy to approach. He's one of the better teacher's I've had. My only complaint is that he throws curve ball questions on exams. Take him if you can.

He's a very good lecturer on EM. He explains the math really well and isn't afraid to tell you how much he is going to curve. The homeworks take forever to do and the exams can be pretty hard. Very helpful if you ask him a specific question

Ask for help on hw, she will help considerably. Great partial credit on exams. Exam questions are fair, but each one has a few true or false that can be specific. Pop quizzes are essentially attendance. Bonus project was offered during the busy time around finals. She explains things well.

The homework can be difficult at times but she will walk you through any question within reason during office hours, which are recorded and posted to Carmen. Tests are a large part of the grade, but they she is very forgiving. The lectures are dry and she takes an abstract approach to the material. Extra credit was during finals so I couldn't do it

Literally the worst professor I've ever had in my life. Told me I need to think more when I asked her for help... Absolutely terrible at communicating any info that you need. Think the exams will reflect what you went over in homeworks and lecture? Not even a little. Drop the class if you have her.

She's a very good professor and extremely fair when it comes to exams and homework assignments. She makes sure everyone understands the material well and her class is very easy so long as you put in the effort. She also gave us a lot of opportunities for extra credit. Very good professor and I definitely recommend taking a class with her.

Agree with the review below; a great teacher with very reasonable expectations. Explains stuff well, and the slides she uses give all the material you need. She did pop quizzes and a project for extra credit. Makes herself available to answer questions, and even helps during exams (gives hints and stuff). The final was cake if you study a little

She is amazing! She puts in the effort to make sure that every student understands the material being taught. Will explaining a topic require her to spend five minutes filling up the blackboard and another half an hour to explain it? SHE'LL DO IT! I highly recommend her.

Kiryung is one of OSU's greatest ECE faculty. He is kind, understanding and does not hesitate to break down material as clearly as possible, to ensure that all of his students understand. He is very helpful in and out of class and wants you to succeed. He frequently asks for feedback on his exams/homework and adjusts grading in a very fair manner.

Professor Lee was nothing short of terrible for ECE 5200. He focused this class on derivation of formulas instead of how to apply these formulas to apply DSP to signals or systems. I can confidently say that I have learned absolutely nothing that will help me in the real world if I were to go into the field of DSP.

Super nice person, and made it clear that he would test us on the fundamentals rather than difficult or trick questions. Let us re-do exams to regain partial credit, and gave lots of opportunities for partial credit, so it should not be hard to get an A. He also really went out of his way to make people feel heard and answer questions.

Prof. Lee was the best! He makes the class very interesting and easily accessible. You can come to live lectures or tune in thru Zoom and he uploads everything to Carmen. Homework can be hard but office hours help a ton! His exams are very fair (open note) and he offers credit back. One of the nicest and most caring professors I've ever had

Very math heavy courses but he explains it well. He makes sure you understand it before moving on. He uses a OneNote for everything, office hours as well which will help you access notes if you did not go for office hours. He is active on Piazza and would reply to your problems quickly which helps if you are studying last minute.

This is honestly one of the best classes I've taken at OSU. He really wants everyone to succeed and will walk you through whatever is confusing you. He gives extra credit for participation, which is so nice. His exams are extremely fair and generally based on concepts from the homework. I highly recommend this class!

His lectures were a bit messy since he took over from another prof and he had to teach based off of someone elses notes but he does a great job clarifying in office hours. His exams were always easy and always gave "make up work" to make up for points you missed on exams. With his own teaching notes, I can see him being one of the departments best
Learned device physics concepts from him. Great teacher.
Very knowledgeable and kind person.

He is a nice and understanding professor but often gets to excited about his research interests and forgets to teach students what we actually need to know. Lectures were often obscure and confusing and when it came time for homework and exams, we had no idea how to actually do the problems. He grades very generously and wants everyone to succeed
Difficult class, but I wouldn't take it with anyone else. Midterms and homeworks can be difficult. Worth your time if you like power or rf devices

Really knows what he is talking about. Very helpful in and out of class. Homework is hard and book is worthless, so ask him your questions. The class is a little disorganized, but is pretty good overall. Prepare to go fast on the midterms.  Many questions with little time.

Awful professor. Didn't respond to emails, made homework problems impossible, very unorganized when it comes to notes, and expected students to know a lot without ever teaching it. Pretty much a self teaching class. Overall, one of my least favorite professors at the university.

I recommend 100 percent going to the classes or at least trying. I had no interest in this class and take it because it is required for my major and I did not go to any class and now I am paying for it. Everything in his notes ends up on the midterms and tests. The homework is not bad either. Not too bad of a class if you put forth effort.

Professor Rajan was extremely helpful, and has become one of my favorite profs at OSU. Make sure you attend class; solid state classes require that you have detailed notes. Exams are largely based off of homework and notes, DO NOT MISS CLASS! Prof. Rajan is always helpful at office hours, and very young and lively.

Dr. Rajan seemed to care more about his research than our class.  When you could catch him in his office he was helpful, however   he would often not be there (even during scheduled hours).  He did not show up to one of our two midterms or the final (TA proctored these) and often gave us questions in the homework or exams that could not be answered

Professor Fiorentini is an outstanding instructor. Her unique approach to teaching control theory through the powertrain as a case-study was highly effective and engaging. Her lectures were clear and concise, and her notes were well-organized and easy to follow. She provided numerous examples and was always available for questions and extra help.

Dr. Lisa is a gem. She really took the role of a supporter for capstone teams and wanted us to succeed. We defined our own requirements, so we just needed to meet them at the end. Only 2 reports and 2 presentations: Proposal, and Final. Everything else was check-ins and working on our projects. The best way to structure capstone, 100% recommend.

Lisa is one of the best capstone professors in the ECE department. Her feedback on group work is extremely helpful and is very fast in responding to emails (even at night). If offered, I highly recommend taking Lisa for capstone as she will make your senior year smooth sailing up until graduation!

Lisa is one of those great professors, and great professional. She is very passionate about controls and even thought the course is related to mechanical system, it is view through a Controls perspective. In general she is extremely detail in her explanations. Homework are fine and exams are what you would expect for grad level course

His lecture content is a bit scrambled, & provided lecture notes are drawn with a computer mouse. However, the homework and exams were all take-home, and there're plenty of examples and supplementary content to get you through the class fairly easily. The class is not taught in a way that sticks with you, but is designed in your favor grade-wise.
Dr. Khan is an easy-going Professor Emeritus. He made the class braindead, though that means you don't really need to pay attention to pass with an A.

I stopped going to class after the first one and still got an A in the course. Easiest engineering course I have ever taken, notes and lectures are super precise and allow you to complete all the assignments in class.

Easiest engineering class you will take at OSU. However, if you actually want to learn the material well Dr. Khan gives you the tools for success. His homework and tests are insanely easy but his lectures are very good and he explains things really well, he also records all of them which is nice.

After two courses with him, he is a really nice professor, and you can skip class to watch the lectures online while still earning 100% on every assignment. I can't say I will remember much beyond this class, though. It's so easy that you never pay enough attention to the course material. I spent 2-4 hours on the class every other week.

If you take this class with khan, theres no doubt this will be one of your easiest classes for the semester. I attended two weeks of lecture and will be ending the semester with an A. Also, his lectures are actually entertaining when you do need to watch them for the take home exams! Definitely recommend!

To give you a sense of the atmosphere in this class, he referred to all of his students as "toxic sewer goblins." You will probably have no idea what's going on and still have an 'A' in the class. HW, midterms, and the final were all online. Helpful outside of class, too.
Khan knows what he's talking about, but makes his classes quite easy overall. All assignments and tests were out-of-class with at least a week to complete.
Best professor ever.

I liked Professor Khan, the class isn't a ton of work and he makes the midterm/final 1 week long and open note. He explains the content very clear and has good notes, but listening in lecture is pretty important if you don't want to spend forever learning the content. Overall I think he is a pretty good professor

His class was a joke. He is funny in his lectures and the content was extremely easy even if you skipped lecture and read through the notes. However, he did pretty much nothing for students and we didn't learn anything beyond absolute basics over the whole semester. It was really just a busy work GPA boost and we did not learn anything useful
Dr. Khan is a great instructor and makes a very difficult class a pleasant experience.

Dr. Khan purposely makes the class easy. Take home & open note EVERYTHING. His posted lectures and notes will tell you how to do all the quizzes and exams. He knows most people will get A/A-'s. You'll learn basic assembly, but not much about microcontrollers.

Furrukh is quite the accomplished dude. He's very lax now tho that he's been teaching over 15 years. All grades in this class were the same, just with different names (quiz, exam, project). They were all take-home, even the final. Basically were just all assembly-coding projects in Code Composer Studio with your Texas Instruments microKhantroller.
His class was super easy.  You dont really need to show up to class except to turn in homework and tests since he records all the lectures. Tests are all open notes.
Really funny and chill guy, I would definitely take this class again with him. You don't have to work that hard for a good grade.

He makes the class really easy. Mostly clear about what he expects from us. He speaks really slowly, but at least posts the lectures online for me to watch on 2x speed. The only problem is that you don't learn too much when you don't have to work for a good grade, but I'm not too displeased by this.

His lecture style kinda sucks, but you don't have to go. He's likeable. Exams are open note, so print off every lesson. Just read through the lessons, watch the lectures, and do the HWs and you'll get an A. Def who you want for 2060, hope he teaches 2020 again soon. The lab portion is incredibly chill compared to FE. Sorta fun and lenient reports.

Very flexible and easy person to talk to about conflicts. Didnt go to class after the first week, watched a few of the online lectures before an exam, did fine on exams even though I did not know what was going on sometimes.

Khan is amazing! He posts everything online, and has open-note exams. There is no reason not to get an A. Just study his notes and bring them to the exam, you'll pass. He's very understanding. If you have 3 exams on the same day, he'll let you reschedule or take it home. Lab reports are a pain. Overall, wish we had more prof. like him.

There's no reason to not do well in this course. Exams are open notes, you can not pay attention in class, print off his notes and homework solutions and have everything to look at on the exam and do really well. He also posts his lectures online but I would recommend downloading them and speeding them up because he talks really slowly.

Dr. Khan teaches on two different levels. On a basic level, you could watch his videos and get an A without much trouble and learn "snippets of knowledge". On a higher level, he provides a comfortable introduction to the subject matter, so that motivated students can read the text cover-to-cover without feeling like any topic they read is new.
Watched all the lecture videos (skipped all the classes) and did all the hw. Got an A without a problem.
Watch the videos, skip class, guaranteed above B+.

Textbook would be helpful for exams, but isn't necessary the screencasts alone can prepare you for the exams. Overall as a teacher he was fairly entertaining, but by no means do you have to come to the lecture to do well. 2060 with Khan was incredibly easy would recommend him to anyone taking this course. Also extra credit for showing up final day.

This class was easy. I'm going to be honest, I did next to nothing all semester and ended up just fine. Definitely not a free A, but you won't work your butt off for a C+. I could not watch lectures as Khan just made so little sense. It felt like he was teaching the material to people already proficient in it.

Khan's classes for ECE 2020 and 2060 were much easier than expected. The tests were a lot easier than they could have been, and they are open-note. As long as you somewhat prepare for tests, you will be fine. Also, lectures are all online, even though they aren't the most helpful.

Khan is the dude you want for ECE2060 and ECE2020. His class is very easy and manageable. TAs are super accessible if you struggle. Exams are graded more leniently than other ECe classes I have taken. If you can do the HW by yourself without help, then you can ace the exams because they are open note and TEXTBOOK.
Easy lectures, homework and exams.

Khan honestly is a good choice to teach this class. Despite lectures feeling like an eternity, he was always able to answer any questions you had. Granted, I learned assembly, though I stopped keeping up with lecture around the 8th week and still finished with an A.
Prof. Khan is very interesting and replies emails very quickly. His homework,quizzes and exams are very easy.

I extremely doubt if he actually prepares for the class. He talks a lot of nonsense. If u just go to the lecture, it's not enough. I have to rewatch the screencasts and google some of terminology because he is not clear!!! Really need to read the book.

Khan clearly had a love and passion for ECE. I admire how much effort he put into lectures and how much he interacted with students. He seemed like a very genuine guy. However, the ECE 2060 course is poorly set up and I couldn't tell you one thing I learned from that class. But Khan himself is a great professor, besides speaking painfully slow.

Prof. Khan is interesting. He does a really good job explaining material. You might fall asleep listening to him in all honesty.  The class is pretty boring for the first 8 weeks. It's not a hard class. It's open note, open text midterms.

Furrukh Khan makes ECE2060 fun and easy. If you watch the screencasts and read the lessons, the HWs are easy. The test are open book and open notes, so they are easy as well. The workload is very manageable, and Furrukh will sometimes even give points to students without them doing anything. Overall, Furrukh makes the class fun and I learned a lot.

Good Professor. Lectures all put online. Homework is relevant to the tests and course. Gentle Grading from TAs and a generous amount of drops and free HW points. Learned a decent amount from the course but Labs could be better made to teach alongside the lecture. Overall, Very good professor to have, I would take again and an A is very much doable.
Fun and Easy but still learned a lot.
Sometimes good at explaining concepts, other times not. Lectures were all posted online for review. Textbook was really only required for the homework problems.
One of the best lecturers I've had at OSU. I'm someone who likes to learn everything inside and out (OCD), and I never left his lectures with a question.

Other than getting used to his accent, his class is quite easy. He goes over the exact material covered on the exams and they are non-cumulative exams. Lab is the worst part of this class. Ensure you get a good lab group or you will hate your life the entire semester. Homework is a bit more complicated than the previous class, but still not bad.

Khan is interested in the material he teaches and he knows how important it is, but he is in no way willing to help his students. I got really behind in his class so I asked him for help but he kept sending me to the TA's who kept sending me back to him. He was rude and didn't seem to care whether or not his students were doing well in his class.
He is a very nice professor.  If you ask for help, he will give it to you.  If you study and go to class, you will get a good grade.

While I had him I did not think that he was a bad teacher, just a little on the lazy side as far as preping for the lectures. The PDFs that he uses are from other quarters. Philipee is the best part of the class. Once you move on from his classes however, you realize his laid back teaching only put you behind. BE PREPARED FOR INDEPENDENT STUDY!!!!
he threw a lot of new material before the final. was not very helpful, he seems uninterested in actually helping students. this professor is not very personable.

not a very good professor. he goes over material too fast. in my opinion going over material too fast is not conductive towards learning. also the labs were extremely difficult for someone like me learning about electrical and computer engineering for the first time.

A really fun guy, but unfortunately not the best of professors.  Lectures are primarily taught by reading off pdf documents and going through copious amounts of examples.  However, he goes through the examples too fast; it would be more conducive to learning if he worked through a few examples slower (and actually wrote them down as he did them).
291 was a bit confusing the way information was taught but it seemed to all come together in the end. Khan is by far one of the best professors though.
291, as opposed to 290, is not so easy. The topics jump around and he's often confusing skipping over basic concepts and relations. I was far less impressed this quarter.
Great professor.  Also has awesome TAs.  If you can have him for EE classes... DO IT!

This guy rules.  He puts a screen cast of every lecture online and all his quizzes and exams are not very hard.  I didn't attend class at all unless there was a quiz and i ended up with almost a 100% in the class. The only tedious part of the class are the labs
Furrukh is great! He loves what he does, he's funny and his hardware oriented approach to teaching makes learning the material easier and more practical.
Best there is. Simple as that. You can tall he loves what he does.
I'm really happy for the rest of the ECE department, and I'mma let them finish, but Prof. Khan is one of the greatest professors of all time. ALL TIME!

If you haven't taking a class with this beast, you are missing out big time. Just saying. If you just keep up and understand the lectures, you will do fine. Everything is posted online so you shouldn't worry about that. Really organized professor , super fun, super helpful.

Prof. Khan is one of the best teachers I ever had. His lectures and labs are fun and at the same time full with up to date ECE knowledge and technologies.Our labs have Tv, video games, and Ipads to play and learn.

Besides the fact that you won't get your midterm back until the last week of the quarter, he's a pretty good teacher.  Puts a lot of effort into his classes and has some witty humor. Had all open note and book quizzes and tests. Best part is playing xbox on the huge lcd he bought for the lab.
Great professor, perhaps the best I have had here at OSU.  Fair grading, posts lectures online, fun labs... what else can you ask for?

Furrukh Khan is the best professor I've had at Ohio State yet.  He records all of his lectures, and puts the screencasts online as well as the notes he explains in class.  He made the labs very interesting and fun to do.  This guy is also hilarious and you will laugh almost every time you go to class.  He also seems to be an impressive comic artist

Prof. Kahn is a great teacher.  He is very clear and funny when he presents during lecture.  For both classes I have taken with him he has provided both his in class notes and screen casts on his lectures so you can go back and watch them if needed.  He is also very available outside of class for help. I would take any class that he is teaching.

Professor Khan is very good.  His examples are very clear and well thought out.  His class is on the easy side and he has never done anything questionable or unfair in the two classes I have take with him.  For ECE 320 you cannot get a better professor.  He tests concepts rather than if you can solve complicated circuits.

One of the best Professors I have ever had at Ohio State. Went to class 1 time a week just to get a laugh and for the quizzes on Monday's because he is hilarious, however his notes teach you everything you need to know.

Phenomenal professor with a funny personality. He makes a convoluted and hard subject painless, clear and seemingly easy! Extraordinarily reasonable midterm/final. His lectures are extremely beneficial. Definitely would recommend for ANY class!

This review is for the first instance of CSE 668 from 2007.  Another reviewer here was quite harsh, in that the class was EXPERIMENTAL and they couldn't expect perfection on a totally innovative class the first try.  Dr. Khan is an excellent instructor, very bright, very motivated.  He was always very helpful, but i always went prepared.

He was a funny, fair professor.  I didn't have any interest in the class but I had to take it.  Everything was open note and nothing too tricky.  No homework, just a couple quizes and midterms.  Makes the content somewhat interesting.  Funny comments at times.  Good Prof.

Class is very easy, never opened the book, just learned from his notes that were provided on his website.  The notes were very unclear at times, but they got the job done.  Also sometimes he's hard to understand and you just have to study the notes by yourself to figure out what's going on.  Open notes quizzes and exams.

Had for ECE300. Decent lecturer, funny, presents directly from PDF files. He posts everything online. Wish he had done a problem on the board every now and then, but the class really was too short to do this. I got and A but didn't learn very much. Good Prof, but they really need to rethink this class.

A terrible instructor. He wasted 8 weeks of the quarter talking about total nonsense, in which he did not assign any homework. Then he assigned the first project during the 9th week of the quarter. He assigned the second project during finals week. He kept on making changes to the project because of the errors in the project. Avoid him!
Very funny, and into what he's teaching. Real laid back. Open note exams.

I really liked this professor. He is very helpful and all his class material is on the web (hw, quiz, tests). I was one of the few people that went to his office hour from the class and he was more than willing to help and explain anything I did not understand. Watch out for tests and quizzes, simple mistake on 1 cost me 20% of midtm Attend class!!

This class was quite easy, but also quite easy to mess up.  What I mean by this is that midterms were generally 2 questions long, and so making a little mistake could earn you -20%.  There is really no excuse for mistake though, because he tells you what the problems are going to be ahead of time, and then you get to use notes and your book.

this class is very easy and not a lot of work...the downside is it is very hard to separate urself from the pack and get an A...i'm pretty sure i aced the final and i aced one of the 2 midterms...i got almost all hmwrk points...so that leaves my "slip-up" on the first midterm, where i "only" beat the average by 15 points, bringing me down to an A-
Easiest class ever. Open book, open notes. I never went and and got an easy A. You learn enough to make it through the class, but you won't really learn anything from him.

Class was slow-paced and easy to follow.  Exams were quite simple; however, the small amount of homework made it difficult to be well prepared.  Professor was happy to answer questions if you visited his office.  An additional perk: he held a drawing to pick 3 random students to treat to dinner at the faculty club during finals week!

All lectues are online so you dont have to take notes or you can just cut class alot. HW is from the book and the test are pretty easy but trickey. overall he is a very good speaker and a pleasure to learn from.
Pretty good prof. Teaches you what you need to know and the exams are quite easy. Funny guy as well. Hey may be lying if he says there is a "lucky duck" day.
If you thought he was easy for 261 you should take him for 682 - even easier.  Very easy, very helpful, teaches exactly what you need to know.  You definitely want this guy teaching your class.
261 is such a cake class, this guy is AWESOME, anyone who fails or does badly in 261 should drop out of double E.  Plus, he talked about movies alot.
very easy, but taught us nothing. you are screwed for subsequent classes if you had him for EE 261

Dr. Khalil is a menace to your GPA and an absolute monster of a professor. He's a walking 7 foot chip generating machine who teaches you everything you would ever want about circuits. Somewhat difficult exams and homework, easier if you actually read the book. Expects participation. Respect.

I honestly dont know how most of us passed this class. I learned nothing and exams (which is what you are graded most heavily on) are very hard. At least for 3000 level courses, he does not seem to understand that he is teaching new concepts that we dont understand yet. Lectures and notes are also extremely hard to follow. Do not recommend!

woof. Hard material with not so great lectures. Was disorganized throughout the semester and I never really knew what to expect. Making sure I retake this class with a different professor and I recommend you do the same!
Avoid at all costs.

7 homeworks and 2 exams, and curving average to the C/C-. I didn't learn in his lectures especially when we were online and I just couldn't read his handwriting. Everything I learned I learned by looking up videos on youtube. He cares but isn't a great teacher.
(in Bibyk's class people also didn't learn anything, but at least it's an easy A)

Honestly, Khalil is not worth taking above Bibyk. Can't read his handwriting when teaching remotely. Decent at teaching in person. During office hours he try and leave asap and sometimes he doesn't really answer your question. About 10 hw and 2 exams, both hard. The final class average is ~70%, with smol curve. Not the best choice for anyone's GPA.

Dr. Khalil is quite knowledgeable about the course subjects and likes to relate to industry a lot. He also likes to help students with career planning by hosting appointments and talks outside of class time.

The tests and homework are hard but aren't graded harshly, with partial credit on all questions. He is very receptive to student feedback.

Seems to have little experience lecturing or designing a class structure. Has an absurd policy that deducts 2% of your grade if he catches you being absent, and no, you do not earn any credit for attendance, only lose. He also retroactively changed the grading scheme because of his poor planning. Somehow Bibyk would've been the better option.
I always enjoy interactive classes where professor pauses and expects an answer as a brainstorming session. He does it non-stop. Makes you comprehend the subject with smart repetitions.

A fantastic professor who challenges all of his students & cares about their success. Well, my grade for the class is a little bit lower than I have expected, but I never regret taking his class. Wanna take his class again, and give him a big hug.
Expect to spend a lot of time doing homework in the lab. Expect 20 hours a week on homework minumum. You will learn a lot but the time needed to be put in is ridiculous.

I have little experience in RFIC before. So this course is like a nightmare to me. I cannot understand most of what he is taught in class. He did not teach basic concepts in RF, but ask you 'why' questions.

Khalil is excellent in explaining situations where "what will happen if" as he was being an interviewer for long time.  But he is not doing well in explaining a 'what' question. You have to read a lot and refer to textbooks to know what are some definitions really are by yourself. All homework and Final Project are related to what he has taught.

His expectations for 5020 are insane. He expects 12 hours a week minimum, to be spent on his 3 CREDIT HOUR class. Said final project should take 80 HOURS to do. Homework and lectures don't line up. Homework overall has higher grade weight than final. "TA" was more helpful than him overall. Should rename class to "Cadence-How I Learned to Hate VLSI"
Good game, well played.  :)

Expect 15-20 hours of homework each week. In addition, there are errors in the homework which were not corrected until a day or two before it was due. The lectures are extremely dull and he moves really fast. His homework is completely different then what he lectures on.
I love him, he is a caring, generous, and extremely knowledge able role model & instructor who cares about his student's success! His exams and hws are hard but worth! I wish he was my older brother!
He is one of the greatest professor I've ever had. If you can fully understand his 5021 class, you are guaranteed a job.

Prof Khalil is an excellent instructor. He once worked in Intel so he taught us what  and how an RF engineer should think. He always asked questions in class to catch your mind. U will learn a lot besides the materials and all of which are very useful. The exams are a bit difficult but if you get deep into the lecture they are  not a problem.

I was at Ohio State for 5 years for my Bachelors and Masters and Dr. Khalil was the best professor I had. He was the sole reason I got interested in circuit design. A perfect mix of a corporate professional and an excellent lecturer, Dr. Khalil had a lot to offer. No job interview in circuits will be difficult if you adapt to his style.
A lot of work and short deadlines.

Great material and very helpful insights to what you have to focus on not just for academic pursuit but also as a professional RF engineer. A must take for any RF engineer who is serious about advancing their knowledge and deepen their understanding but also be ready to spend a lot of time to review the material and do the homework.
Professional  and helpful! Materials are tough but he is not stingy on giving good grades

Professor Khalil is one of the best EE instructors I've had.  He runs a challenging class but if you work hard you will learn more than you could anywhere else.  He also tends to put a lot of weight on the final project, so don't blow it off.

Prof Khalil is one of the best professors I've ever had.  He is very difficult and gives hard exams that test over concepts.  Most likely, you will suffer throughout the class, but you will come out having learned so much and your grade will be higher than you expect.  Dr. Khalil is very kind and truly loves helping his students. Very inspiring.

I really liked this guy. He wants you to learn and is willing to slow down the pace of class to ensure that you do. Gives extensive homeworks that test your mastery of the subject; exams are tricky, but he grades only four of five possible questions. If you try, you will get at least a B.
very good professor, very well organized lecture material
Teaching is good but difficult in exam

By far one of the best ECE professors at Ohio State. I learned so much in his class and it helped apply directly to some of the undergraduate research I completed for the university. Dr. Ertin is funny, kind, patient, considerate, and is exceptionally good at spelling out material clearly and effectively. Exams were difficult but perfectly fair.

Emre is great Professor! He does a good job explaining the concepts, and gives real life examples, which helps conceptualize. He's pretty helpful in office hours, and is very responsive at all hours on Piazza, a class question website.

A great choice if you want to learn about radars, MIMO system, and signal processing related topics. Funny on a regular basis, humble, kind, always be there for students, and reasonable workload for his class. He did a great job first time teaching the class, I am sure with experience he will be the world-class teacher.

He doesn't know what he is teaching. His slides are right from the text book. He doesn't explain why, but just that things just happen and we have to accept it because the equation exists. Single handedly ruined my impression of OSU.
He is not that great at explaining concepts. He is an amazing human being and pretty laid back.

Very laid back, willing to help, and fair with his grading. Textbook is dense but it's not needed. Tests can be tough but he allows cheat sheets.  No curve, but he gives many bonus opportunities that act as one. He is completely fine with project and homework collaboration as long as you turn in your own work. If you try, you will do well.

Nice professor. He would go over class examples but expect you to work out problems on your own. The exams are questions pulled straight out of the book or with a little bit of a twist to them, so definitely practice. He grades a bit harsh but if you talk to him about it in office hours youll get lots of your points back. Tells you whats on exam
Easy exam and homework. No attendance needed.
Very unclear lectures. If you learn the material on your own, the homework and exams are relatively easy. Would not recommend.

Professor Guo does not grade on your ability to understand the material, only if you can write the correct answer at the end of your work. During office hours, he could give you the method used to solve a homework problem, and then take off points on the same question when grading it for not using the "correct" method. Do not recommend.

Boring and impossible to hear, even with a mic. Students gave up on trying to ask him to speak louder. Little to no point in going to class due to lack of volume and reading straight off of his power points, which are online and straight out of the books. Sub-par prof. Nice guy.
